hierarchy.meeting_title: 5490683 - Wisp & Willow Florals - sales_pitch - Discussion with Oscar Fuentes

sections.text: Megan Foster: Hi Oscar—thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep this tight. I wanted to show you how Issue_Tracker helps teams like yours turn a messy stream of support tickets and “is this real?” bug reports into a prioritized, deduped set of issues that engineering can trust.
Oscar Fuentes: Hi Megan. Sure—what’s the big difference versus what we already do with Zendesk and Jira?

Megan Foster: Great question. We don’t replace either. Issue_Tracker sits between them and standardizes what we call an “issue object”—a theme or root cause, with evidence attached from the original conversations, plus who’s impacted and what it’s costing you. Instead of 40 tickets that feel similar, it clusters them into one issue, shows the trend velocity, and keeps it linked to the Jira work you create.
Oscar Fuentes: Deduping sounds useful, but we’ve tried tagging and macros. It still gets noisy. How does clustering actually work in practice?

Megan Foster: Practically, it continuously ingests from Zendesk or Intercom, groups similar reports into clusters, and then gives you a clean view of “these are the top recurring problems.” The part customers tend to like is the evidence panel: for any cluster, your engineering manager can click in and see representative examples, platform or device breakdowns, and whether the volume is rising week over week—before committing someone to an on-call fix.
Oscar Fuentes: That would help. My team spends a lot of time arguing whether something is widespread or just a couple loud customers.

Megan Foster: Exactly. And the second piece—where teams see impact fast—is issue prioritization. Issue_Tracker ranks each cluster with an explainable score based on things you configure: frequency and velocity, severity tags, customer tier or ARR, churn-risk flags, and segment importance. So instead of “support says it’s urgent” versus “product says later,” you have a shared, defensible logic for what to fix next.
Oscar Fuentes: Explainable is key. If it’s a black box score, product won’t trust it.

Megan Foster: Totally. The score breaks down the “why”—for example: “High velocity + affecting top-tier customers + churn-risk flagged.” And you can have different views by team. Support can look at SLA risk, product can view impact versus effort, and execs can see revenue exposure. It’s the same underlying issues—just framed for what each group needs.
Oscar Fuentes: How much setup are we talking? We’re a small team, so heavy implementation is a non-starter.

Megan Foster: Low lift. Most teams start with Zendesk/Intercom ingestion and a Jira linkage. Then we map a few simple fields—like customer tier, segment, or churn-risk—either from your CRM or whatever source you already use. You can begin with very basic weighting, then refine as you see what’s working. The goal is value in days, not months.
Oscar Fuentes: We don’t always have clean “tier” data. Sometimes the ticket just comes in with an email and a vague complaint.

Megan Foster: That’s common. Two ways teams handle it: first, you can start with what you do have—severity tags, frequency, velocity—so you still get clustering and a prioritized list. Second, as you connect CRM context, the system gets smarter about impact. Even partial data helps because it’s about directional prioritization: which issues are both widespread and business-critical.

Oscar Fuentes: Ok. Let me ground this: we’re Wisp & Willow Florals—our busiest pain points are order changes and delivery scheduling. Support gets flooded, and engineering gets pulled in when something seems like a systemic bug.

Megan Foster: That’s a perfect fit for the use case I mentioned. Imagine you get a spike of “can’t change delivery date” complaints. Today it’s scattered across tickets, maybe a few chats, and someone pings engineering with screenshots. With Issue_Tracker, those get clustered into one issue automatically, with trend velocity showing the spike, and evidence showing common patterns—like it’s happening mostly on mobile Safari, or only for certain order types. Your engineering manager can validate “this is real and widespread” in minutes rather than chasing anecdotes.
Oscar Fuentes: The platform breakdown would be huge. We’ve had issues that only happen on certain devices and it takes forever to confirm.

Megan Foster: Exactly. And then prioritization helps answer the follow-up question: “Do we drop everything to fix it?” If that cluster is impacting high-value customers, or a segment you care about—say your corporate accounts—it rises. If it’s low volume and low impact, it doesn’t dominate the queue just because it’s loud.
Oscar Fuentes: How do you handle the “status” part? One of our biggest internal problems is people asking, “Is this fixed? Is it known? Who owns it?”

Megan Foster: Issue_Tracker keeps a searchable history of the issue and its decision trail—what the status is, when it changed, which Jira work is linked, and which customer conversations are the source. So when support asks “what do I tell this customer,” they’re not guessing or DM’ing engineers. They can see: “Known issue, fix in progress, linked ticket ABC-123,” and even pull the most relevant context.
Oscar Fuentes: That would reduce a lot of internal back-and-forth. But does it create another place people have to check?

Megan Foster: That’s the balance we’re careful about. We’re not trying to become “yet another dashboard.” The idea is that Zendesk stays where support works, Jira stays where engineering works—but the issue layer becomes the shared truth that connects them. So your workflow becomes: tickets and conversations flow in, Issue_Tracker clusters and prioritizes, then engineering work flows out to Jira with traceability back to the cluster.
Oscar Fuentes: Makes sense. What would you need from us to show whether this works for our data?

Megan Foster: For a next step, I’d suggest a 30–45 minute working session. We’ll look at your last 30 days of support volume—no heavy prep—and identify the top recurring themes. Then we’ll walk through how clustering would group them and how prioritization would rank them based on the business rules you care about. If you’re open to it, we can also discuss linking to Jira so the “is it fixed” loop is closed.
Oscar Fuentes: I’m interested. Who should join on our side—support lead? engineering?

Megan Foster: Ideally you, your support lead, and whoever triages bugs on the engineering side—often an engineering manager. That way we can validate both the evidence view (for engineering) and the support workflow benefits. If that’s too many people for the first call, we can start with you and support, and bring engineering into a follow-up.
Oscar Fuentes: Let’s do it with support and engineering—if we’re evaluating, I want them to see it firsthand.

Megan Foster: Perfect. I’ll send a calendar invite for a 45-minute session and include a brief checklist: which support channel you want to start with, and whether you’re using Jira or Linear. We’ll keep it simple and focused on two outcomes: reducing noise via clustering, and aligning on what to fix next with explainable prioritization.
Oscar Fuentes: Sounds good. Send me a couple time options for next week and I’ll loop them in.
Megan Foster: Will do. Before we hop, any concern you want me to address in that session—security, data retention, anything like that?
Oscar Fuentes: Security will come up, but I think the bigger question is whether it actually saves time for engineering. If you can show that validation workflow clearly, that’ll win them over.

Megan Foster: Got it—I'll center the demo on the engineering manager flow: open a cluster, review representative examples, platform breakdowns, trend velocity, and then link it cleanly to Jira. I’ll send those time options today.
Oscar Fuentes: Great—looking forward to it.
